page.title: 01Mountains S of Llyn Ogwen
page.content: This is a classic site for the study of geological, botanical and physical features of a mountain environment. It is the product of glacial activity, with cwms, corrie lakes, arretes and moranic deposits. Heights vary between 1,100 and 2,200 feet, with precipitous slopes. The landscape also results from the underlying geology, mainly ordouician and silurian volcanics with shales, slates and grits. The main south facing slope is slightly less steep; Fescue Sward dominates. Elsewhere heather grows on acid soils, and the summits are covered with still developing rock detritus. The area supports hardy sheep and a flock of feral goats; Arctic-Alpine flora survives. Entirely within the Snowdonia National Park, approximately two-thirds is a national nature reserve. As such,
